title: Is now the worst time for game balance?
body:
I know there have been times or patches that was crazy. Release Xin, release Leblanc, League of Cleavers, League of Warmogs, the time when Bruisers were dominating everything, heal/poke meta etc to name a few, but I feel like at least, during these past instances, it was only 1-2 things that was blatantly unbalanced.

Now it feels like, the jungle is super unfair cause only a handful of champs can excel in it, mages have been getting pushed aside because of the mana regen nerfs PLUS the athenes/morello's nerf PLUS the removal of DFG, while resourceless champs still have no issues. Squishy supports are getting nerfed while their tankier counterparts are still amazing. Jungle and Support gold income are still unimpressive. Jungle XP is ridiculously low. Champs who has so many free stats or multiple effects on a single skill and so many more issues that are so blatant right now.

It feels like the balance team is playing a different game than us. They even admitted that Lee and Zed are really strong, and yet they nerf Sona again. Their goal was to have a more diverse jungle, but they increase the cost of the jungling item, punishing the squishy/tanky junglers who cleared a lot slower than the AD/bruiser or junglers with sustain.

WHAT IS HAPPENING

One issue is that those problems span multiple teams, and my ability to talk about champion updates is pretty limited. I'm not an expert on most of their projects, and a lot of stuff is always in flight, and talking about any project before it's ready can be really dangerous and disappointing if the project hits problems late in the process. 

That being said, there are posts I could hop into more often. Life at Riot is a pretty big adjustment, even for someone who has been making games for a long time. Communication, as I've already admitted to, is a spot where I have a tremendous amount of room to grow. 

Tiny Caveat, we do still look at those champions more than people realize. We recently shipped the small update to Anivia's Q visuals to help her have some better feedback on her threat range. Fearless, I appreciate your boldness walking into a firestorm like this. And I know you're under tons of pressure from all directions with regards to design. And I realise you've got a huge load of work on your plate, and that the community feedback is just as often uselessly unhelpful as it is helpful.

You are a leader. You are a Rioter that people look up to. People will make degrading comments, people will misinterpret information, people will  question your motives. And as both an Eagle Scout and as the "leader" so to speak of a nationally recognized ethics debate team (since everyone else graduated, I'm now in position to help get everybody on the team currently up to speed), I can understand how bad it feels when a statement made is derogatory towards you, whether it be from simple miscommunication, or opposition to a stance, or simply nothing aside from unpopularity with the crowd. Granted, none of these are on the same scale as a multi-million dollar company, but I can sympathise with how it feels to a certain extent.

However, these are the burdens of being a leader. And a leader's job, as you've said so many times, isn't necessarily to be popular, or to be perfect, or to even make 100% certain that he's interpreted correctly by the people he leads. Granted, these are all goals and pluses, but they aren't the core purpose of leaders. However, one of the core aspects of being a leader is being able to communicate with those that follow you. Yes, it means there will be criticism. It means there will be opposition. 

What's important to understand from a leader's perspective, though, isn't that people hate you making posts and hate that you're posting to us. People may dislike the content you post, but despite the downvotes on posts, and despite the criticism, I guarantee that you will never encounter a post that reads, "Fearless, stop posting on the forums." Criticism of content is inevitable, but communication between a leader and his followers is necessary and of utmost importance, despite being very time consuming. Giving an unpopular opinion is one thing; these opinions may indeed be for the better of the whole despite the cries of the few.  However, leaving a group of followers in the dark, wondering, is an entirely different beast.

As leaders, we are responsible for maintaining the integrity of the whole mechanism. As leaders, this means making sometimes incredibly controversial decisions. There will never be unanimity with regards to anything that requires a decision to be made. But as leaders, it is our job to inform those we lead about the decisions we've made and why we've chosen to make those decisions, regardless of the recoil we may receive.

In the end, the entire community is aware that you are acting in the community's best interest, even if it doesn't appear to be so from the initial feedback. Most of the crew here understands not all changes can happen immediately, but people are impatient. It's part of the human problem. Just be patient with the community, be a leader, and realise that even if we "boo" your content as it stands when it first is released, we truly appreciate the fact you cared to post and give us context about changes.

We are on your side.
